habitat_description:
The distribution of this species extends from the Balcones Escarpment of central Texas south to the Gulf Coastal Plain of Texas. In Mexico, populations occur in Coahuila, Tamaulipas, central Veracruz, Hidalgo, and Puebla. The western edge of its distribution in Mexico extends in Aguascalientes and northern Michoacan (Camper 1996; Camper and Dixon 1994).  Within its range, this species occupies riparian zones, bare rock, talus, scree, grassland, desert, shrubland, and various woodland habitats.

Preferred habitats include tropical dry forest, semideciduous forest, canyons, woodlands of pine, juniper, and oak, rocky stream courses, grasslands, and pond edges. In Texas, this species is found in savanna and Tamaulipan thorn woodland; also commonly associated with streambeds and ponds (Tennant 1998; Werler and Dixon 2000).

This species burrows in or using soil, fallen logs, and leaf litter. It is also known to retreat into deep crevices or underground in cold weather.  The eggs are laid in abandoned small mammal burrows.

Often found using vegetation found along rivers and creeks as cover. Also associated with drier, more sparsely vegetated areas where live oak and mesquite are used as cover. Microhabitats occupied by this snake characterize the species as arboreal and terrestrial, but still using soil and leaf litter as shelter in cold weather.
